text: SANA MOHAMMED: Good afternoon.

Family, friends, faculty,
staff, Mayor Bloomberg,

and Dean Nohria, and, of
course, the class of 2019.
I am Sana Mohammed.

TRISTON FRANCIS: I
am Triston Francis.

And we are so grateful to
have served as your student
association co-presidents.

SANA MOHAMMED: A little
more than two years ago,

we read those magical words
in our admissions letter.
The answer is yes.

It was a moment that changed the
course of our lives, a moment

that would have
never been possible

without the help
of a community--

family, friends, colleagues,
mentors, partners--

many of whom are in
the audience today.

This day is possible only
because of your love, support,
and encouragement.
We can not thank you enough.
HBS has challenged us.

But the community
that we've built here

has enabled us to overcome
those challenges and grow.

For every case we
could not crack,

there was a discussion
group member
willing to lend a helping hand.

For every club that
needed to be run,

there was a batch
of student leaders

willing to give up their time
to benefit us, their peers.

For every job we
were interested in,

there was a classmate with
relevant work experience
willing to help us prepare.

In the past two
years, Triston and I

have had the unique opportunity
to be fortunate enough

to see our peers exhibit
exceptional leadership
in building our HBS community.

And what we've learned
is that there are
two keys to community building.
The first is being vulnerable.

The second is giving without
expectation of return.

TRISTON FRANCIS: As a
sophomore in high school,

I discovered that
I was dyslexic.

What could have been
devastating news was actually
a breath of fresh air.

Up until that point,
I had spent my days

avoiding teachers in
the classroom for a fear

that I was not intelligent
enough to speak up.

I often spent my
nights crying myself

to sleep filled with
the anxiety that

came with the fear of having
to go to school the next day.
I felt alone.

Rather than asking
for help, I decided

to pour additional
hours on the problem.

And by doing this,
I was able to claw
my way through high school.

As a college freshman, I
had the reading fluency
of a 12-year-old.

And again, I attempted
to overcome this

by pouring more, and more,
and more time into everything
that I did.

When I graduated from college
and entered the workplace,

I used that high school
mentality once again.

And this approach seemed
to be working for a while
until I came to HBS.

The sheer volume of
reading that we've

had to do these past few
years made this approach

of pouring more
hours unsustainable.

For example, I remember during
our first week of classes,

I spent over four hours
preparing for the Toby Johnson

case, a case which took
many of our classmates
less than an hour to complete.
I was reading cases non-stop.
I was not sleeping.
I wasn't speaking in class.

I was missing out on social
events and opportunities
to meet our classmates.

I felt very much on
the verge of giving up.

But instead, I finally
decided to ask for help.

I reached out to a close friend
of mine, our classmate Lindsey

Morrow, and told her about
my academic struggles.

Lindsey looked me straight
in the eyes and said Triston,
you need help.
Reach out to your professors.
Tell them you're struggling.

And you better do this by the
next time I see you or else.

And I'm seeing a few smiles
from people that know Lindsey.

She may have used a little
bit more harsh language.

But there are some
children in the audience

and this is a family
friendly event.

But that tough love is
exactly what I needed.

I met one on one with
each of my professors.

And they provided
tremendous support.

One clear example of the
support came from my operations
professor, Willy Shih.

He urged me to
simply raise my hand

and explained that, if I needed
to, he would stall for a bit

so that I had a moment to gather
my thoughts before speaking.

Simply having this
offer on the table

provided me with
the courage I needed
to participate in the classroom.

This made me realize
that it wasn't so much

the volume of work
that I had been

battling all of these
years, but rather

the psychological baggage that
I carried with me from years

of academic struggles and
feeling as though I was not
intelligent enough.

If it was not for caring
classmates like Lindsey

and professors like
Professor Shih,

I would have had a
miserable experience at HBS.

I certainly would not have
run for student association

co-president or taken on any
sort of activities outside
of the classroom.

This experience of letting my
guard down and being vulnerable

taught me the
importance of asking
for help from our community.

SANA MOHAMMED:
Working with Triston,

I've admired his incredible
work ethic as many of you

can probably attest to with
his 6:00 AM school-wide emails.

I think that this work ethic
is in part a byproduct of how
he navigated his dyslexia.

Sometimes challenges
in our lives
can also lead to blessings.

I learned this
lesson growing up.

My younger brother
[INAUDIBLE] was

born with a
developmental disability.
He has severe autism.

This means that
as a 26-year-old,

he has the intellectual
capacity of a four-year-old.
He can't read.

He can speak but his
sentences are broken.
He also has epilepsy.

Once a week, he has a
seizure when he's sleeping.

So this means he can
never sleep alone.

I remember once when
I was in high school,
he fell asleep on the couch.

And I thought I could
take a quick shower
and just slip away.
But I was wrong.

He had a seizure
while I was away.

He fell, hit his head on the
tile floors, and bruised.

I remember being so
disappointed in myself

for not being there
because I should have been.

He's not just my parents'
responsibility but mine.

I went to college in
Houston to be there for him
and I lived at home.

When you aspire to be
ever-present for someone,

it may seem like you
are giving a lot.

But giving in itself is
an enormous blessing.

And I know my relationship
with my brother has been.

From him, I've learned so
much, like the pure excitement

in his eyes when we
go to the car wash
or when we're on a plane.

He has taught me the
importance of finding the joy
in the little things in life.

He has taught me that there is
an immense reward in giving,

that giving fills your heart
with compassion, gratitude,
and love.
It feeds your soul.
It deepens relationships.

And it breeds life
into community.

I know I've experienced
that firsthand here at HBS.

Unaccustomed to
living alone and away

from my brother and my family,
I felt very lonely here
during the first year.

I felt like I had no
one to turn to for help.
But I was wrong.

The HBS community has been there
for me every step of the way.

From my section mate who
helped me move my kitchen

table into my apartment to my
close friend who, unprompted,

sent me a book of poetry over
the summer to help me deal

with heartbreak, from the
leaders of the WSJ review

sessions who were the only
reason I made it through finals

[INAUDIBLE],, to the
organizers of the Japan trek

and the Machu Picchu trek that
exposed me to opportunities

I never would have
had on my own,

these experiences here have
helped me create a family
that I'm sad to leave.

As SA co-president, we
have had the opportunity

to see countless classmates
from section officers

to conference organizers
give without the expectation
of return.

TRISTON FRANCIS: And we have
also had the opportunity

to see classmates with a strong
desire to also be vulnerable,

whether that means speaking
up in a class that's

outside of your
comfort zone or sharing

your personal story in
front of your section
through a [INAUDIBLE].

SANA MOHAMMED: And in being
vulnerable and sharing

their ideas and their
stories, our classmates

have been giving
to us every day.

It is this desire
to be vulnerable

and again that excites us
most about the class of 2019,

because we know if we
are going to be leaders

who make a difference
in the world,
we need to build community.

And to build community, we
need to be vulnerable and help
others be vulnerable.

We need to give and
help others give.

TRISTON FRANCIS: As we
continue on in our lives,

community is going to
become even more important.

Fortunately, Harvard
Business School
is not a two year experience.

This journey that we've
been on lasts a lifetime.

SANA MOHAMMED: We are
leaving here today

with the HBS community in our
corner to comfort us, advise
us, and challenge us.
So we ask you to remember this.

TRISTON FRANCIS:
Community is not
possible without vulnerability.

SANA MOHAMMED: And there
is just an immense reward

in giving to your community
as there is in receiving.

TRISTON FRANCIS:
Class of 2019, as we

embark on this next
journey of our lives,

may we always have the courage
to lead with vulnerability

and the compassion to give
of ourselves regularly.

SANA MOHAMMED: Thank
you for being a part
of this lifelong community.
[APPLAUSE]
